results.title: The Blackbird = La Merle
results.brief_description: Norman McLaren imparts unusual activity to an old French-Canadian nonsense song. Simple white cut-outs on pastel backgrounds provide lively illustrations. The folksong, (Mon Merle), is sung in French by the Trio Lyrique of Montreal. This, the only white blackbird in creation, is a wonderful amalgam of Buster Keaton, Marcel Marceau and McLaren.

results.title: The Black pirate. - [Edited version]
results.creator_credit: Saul J. Turell, Paul Killiam and Gregstan Enterprises
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History of the Motion Picture”.
An edited and narrated presentation of the duels, sea battles and acrobatics in the ‘Black Pirate’ an adventure film made in 1926 starring Douglas Fairbanks. Includes the famous sliding-down-the-sail stunt. Also stars Billie Dove.

results.title: The biology of behavior
results.creator_credit: Harry Ratner, David Stone, Steven Talley and Coastline Community College
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology: the study of human behavior”.
Humans are quick thinking, quick acting animals. This ability to react is controlled by the nervous system, which in turn is controlled by a complex system of neurotransmitters in the brain. This program examines the operation of these neurotransmitters, their effect on individual personality and what happens when these networks break down due to neurotransmitter diseases, in particular, Parkinson’s Disease.

results.title: The Biological control of insects [Excerpt]
results.brief_description: Shows a number of insect pests close-up in the laboratory. Outlines the success with which they have been controlled by their natural enemies and by the use of virus diseases. Suitable for secondary years 7-12.

results.title: The Biological control of insects
results.brief_description: Shows some aspects of the entomologist’s work in his attempts to control insect pests by the use of their natural enemies. In telling the story of biological control the following pests are shown in cloe-up: cottony cushion scale, cabbage moth, green vegetable bug, cabbage white butterfly, vegetable weevil and Queensland fruit fly. Their natural enemies include predators, parasites and diseases.

results.title: The Bill. When opportunity knocks
results.brief_description: ‘The Bill’ is a UK police drama that explores both criminals and police. These three mid-nineties episodes are good examples of the series’ true to life stories of crimes, criminals and the police that have to deal with the seedier side of life in East London. ‘Beg borrow or steal’ (1994, produced by Pat Sandys, directed by Gill Wilkinson): vagrants are targeted, in particular a drunk and a young beggar mother. The episode explores what can happen when the police are forced to become involved with people who don’t appreciate their help. ‘Street life’ (1995, produced by Pat Sandys, directed by Paul Unwin): an embarrassed married businessman confesses to being mugged whilst in the company of a prostitute. The undercover operation ensues involving C.I.D. officers. The unsavoury lives of prostitutes and their pimps are revealed whilst the businessman becomes increasingly reluctant to help the police. ‘When opportunity knocks’ (1995, produced by Richard Handford, directed by Laurence Moody): when a dodgy door to door car cleaner may be connected to a string of burglaries turns out to be a ladies man, C.I.D. use a new WPC undercover as bait.

results.title: The Bill. Waiting for Frank
results.brief_description: ‘The Bill’ is a UK police drama that explores both criminals and police. ‘Waiting for Frank’ (1996, produced by Mike Dormer, directed by Robert Del Maestro): some of Sunhill’s C.I.D. police officers spin a tangled web playing the part of petty criminals at a dog racing track. The aim is to catch a man who thinks he’s in luck, helping with a counterfeit money deal. ‘Cast of shadows’ (1998, produced by Michael Simpson, directed by Chris Lovett): an attempted abduction of a schoolgirl leads two C.I.D. officers to Manchester where they are on the trail of a protection racket. A surprise for everyone when the infamous Frank Burnside appears connected. Burnside, a former Sunhill officer is now on the wrong side of the law, or is he?

results.title: The Bill. In on the game
results.brief_description: ‘The Bill’ is a UK police drama that explores both criminals and police. ‘In on the game’ (1995, produced by Mike Dormer, directed by Pip Broughton): its the early hours of the morning and a car has suspiciously stopped. Two Sun Hill officers investigate. They find drugs, money, cards and razor wire - a sophisticated lady and her male companion end up in the cells. An undercover operation is in jeopardy and a keen young policeman is confused. ‘Spill’ (1996, produced by Chris Clough, directed by John Strickland): its action stations in this one hour special episode when a tanker overturns, causing a strange smelling liquid to pour out into the nighttime suburban streets. The appropriate police training comes into play as the area is cordoned off and the surrounds evacuated. Police work hand in hand with the fire brigade and ambulance officers. After the dramas die down it is up to Sun Hill to find the cause of the accident. The story becomes intriguing as the investigation leads them to the haulage company and the dead truck driver.

results.title: The Bill. Gentleman Jim
results.brief_description: ‘The Bill’ is a UK police drama that explores both criminals and police. ‘Gentleman Jim’ contains three episodes of ‘The Bill’ featuring Jim Carver (Mark Wingett). Wingett wrote the first of these three episodes. ‘Saved’ (1995, produced by Pat Sandys, directed by Jeremy Silberston): back in his drinking days Jim Carver is loosing his faith in the police force and in particular, his usefulness. To combat his so called “desk fatigue”, he is called to help in a raid on a crack house. Jim helps a prostitute - restoring his sense of worth. ‘True to life player’ (1997, produced by Chris Clough, directed by Simon Meyers): focuses on a once local boy’s rise to fame as a footballer who is accused of rape by an underage girl. Is she lying, or is he? As the story unfolds the audience is in doubt while Jim Carver plays his role as investigating officer. ‘Gentleman Jim’ (1997, produced by Pat Sandys, directed by Mike Vardy): Jim is teamed up with an overly enthusiastic uniformed officer on secondment in C.I.D. Her drive and initiative conflicts with the slightly stale and crabby Jim. Experience wins over enthusiasm and Jim reveals himself as the decent man and policeman that he is.
